title: Join D-REP
heading:
We are growing a world-class team of designers, engineers, scientists, and makers inventing the future, specifically exploring how data representations and interactions can be more than the current status quo (i.e., flat 2D desktop visualizations). This positioning presents itself as a creative opportunity to innovate the future while addressing current limitations.

Our innovations and “out-of-the-box” thinking enable us to situate data into mediums and contexts that have never been considered (e.g., dome-scale visualizations; 3D-printed network visualizations). Through this stance, we present new data representation paradigms that are unique to our technical strengths.

subheading.title: OPEN POSITIONS AND OPPORTUNITIES
subheading.text: We welcome curious, motivated individuals who are excited about bridging technology, science, and human experience. We embrace diverse perspectives, experiences, and backgrounds. Our lab thrives at the intersection of machine learning/AI, human-computer interaction, data visualization, and computational design. Whether you are a graduate student, postdoc, undergrad, or visiting researcher, there are many ways to get involved. Below is an overview of open roles, expected qualifications, and how to apply.

why.title: Why Join Us
reasons: Work on cutting-edge problems at the convergence of ML/AI, mixed reality, physical interaction, and cognition
Collaborate across disciplines—computational design, engineering, science, psychology
Gain experience in prototyping, user studies, fabrication, design, and visualization
Opportunities to publish and present in top-tier venues in HCI, visualization, AR/VR, cognitive science, and beyond
Be part of an interdisciplinary team of deep thinkers and brilliant makers

positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher 1: XR, Physicalization, Perceptual-Cognitive Studies (1 funded position)

content.text: We seek a postdoc to lead hands-on work in areas including mixed-reality interfaces for scientific domains, interactive data physicalization, or perceptual-cognitive studies of novel visualizations.

listing.title: In general, we are interested in researchers in these directions:
items: Leveraging math and computation to advance the fundamental science and understanding of interactive data representations
Using computational fabrication and geometry to expand the multifunctionality of data physicalizations for sensing, output modalites, mechanical behavior, computational, and actuation
Developing hardware and/or computational design tools for interactive data representations
Develop and refine advanced reinforcement learning to generate, explore, and optimize 3D printed physicalizations

A wild card: If you believe your expertise is not listed above but could spark a radical synergy with the D-REP lab, we encourage you to reach out and pitch ideas. For example, you might be an expert in neuroscience, soft robotics, or architecture and are curious about exploring novel intersections with data physicalization, mixed-reality, or computational fabrication.

listing.title: Preferred Qualifications
items: Strong track record of independent research (publications, demos, prototypes)
Excellent project management skills, independence, self-motivation, organizational skills, and attention to detail
Strong technical and programming skills in languages such as Python, C++, or similar, with experience in frameworks to build interactive systems (e.g. AR/VR), computational fabrication pipelines
Proficiency in handling and analyzing large, heterogeneous datasets (environmental, climate, remote sensing) using Python, C++, or similar languages
Create and implement physical or digital prototypes by using computational methods
Experience conducting human-subject studies
Background in computer science, HCI, cognitive science, or computational design
Ability to write and publish across interdisciplinary venues
Aptitude to work in collaborative teamwork across disciplines

listing.title: How to Apply
listing.text: Send following materials to the D-REP co-directors (Sandra and Takanori):
items: CV
representative publications or portfolio
short research statement (2 pages max)
two or three ideas you are excited to explore in our lab

positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher 2: Machine learning/AI for visualization and physicalization, large-scale 3D visualization (1 funded position)

content.text: We seek a postdoc to lead hands-on work in areas including machine learning/AI for visualization and physicalization, or effective rendering and design of large-scale 3D data representations.

listing.title: In general, we are interested in researchers in these directions:
items: Leveraging math and computation to advance the fundamental science and understanding of interactive data representations
Developing machine learning and AI techniques to extract critical shapes/structures from high-dimensional data and networks
Developing 3D rendering techniques suitable to visualize large-scale high-dimensional and network data in an immersive environment
Studying data patterns that can be better captured by 3D data representations than 2D visualizations

A wild card: If you believe your expertise is not listed above but could spark a radical synergy with the D-REP lab, we encourage you to reach out and pitch ideas. For example, you might be an expert in bioinformatics, astronomy, mathematics, or architecture and are curious about exploring novel intersections with machine learning, data visualization, mixed-reality, or computational fabrication.

listing.title: Preferred Qualifications
items: Strong track record of independent research (publications, demos, prototypes)
Excellent project management skills, independence, self-motivation, organizational skills, and attention to detail
Strong mathematical, statistical, and/or computational background to solve complex problems (e.g., dimensionality reduction, manifolds, network analysis)
Strong technical and programming skills in languages such as Python, C++, JavaScript, or similar, with experience in frameworks to build interactive systems in AR/VR environments or Web UI
Proficiency in handling and analyzing large, heterogeneous datasets using Python, C++, or similar languages, with machine learning/AI models
Background in computer science, HCI, cognitive science, or computational design
Ability to write and publish across interdisciplinary venues
Aptitude to work in collaborative teamwork across disciplines

content.text: We are seeking 2-4 Ph.D. students for the upcoming admissions cycle (Fall 2026 incoming class), through the University of Arizona's Computer Science Department. In addition to applying through the official application portals, you are encouraged to contact the D-REP co-directors (Sandra and Takanori) with listed items below. We seek students who combine strong technical foundations with creativity and interdisciplinary thinking.

listing.title: Areas of Emphasis
items: Machine learning/AI technologies for visualization and physicalization (e.g., dimensionality reduction)
3D large-scale visualizations for network and high-dimensional data
AR/VR applications for data-driven discovery and analysis in STEM domains (e.g. optics, material science)
Interactive computing applications to improve engagement and learning in AI and data science
Computational design pipelines using machine learning and data-driven design optimization to fabricate interactive 3D printed data objects for network physicalizations
Empirical studies on investigating the perceptual effectiveness of data physicalizations

listing.title: More broadly, we are looking for students in one or multiple of these directions.
items: Leveraging math and computation to advance the fundamental science and understanding of interactive data representations
Using computational fabrication and geometry to expand the multifunctionality of data physicalizations for sensing capabilities, output modalites, mechanical behavior, and actuation
Develop and refine advanced reinforcement learning to generate, explore, and optimize 3D printed physicalizations
Developing hardware and/or computational design tools for interactive data representations

listing.title: What to Include When You Apply
listing.text: To help us understand your potential fit, please submit following materials to the D-REP co-directors (Sandra and Takanori). Please note in your email whether you have external fellowships and share both concrete ideas and a broader vision for Ph.D. projects that connect with D-REP’s research scope.
items: CV
portfolio or representative sample work (projects, prototypes, publications, demos)

research statement (please include: 1. Your research interests and motivations, 2. skills/technical expertise, 3. what you hope to gain from working at D-REP, 4. potential project ideas or directions)

content.text: We welcome research associates, visiting scholars, and interns (undergraduate or graduate) from diverse backgrounds, both domestically and internationally. Projects can be short- or mid-term, and may be paid or volunteer depending on funding and role.

listing.title: Expectations & Duration
items: Commitment of at least 6 months is preferred (for productivity and training)
Prior experience in programming, prototyping, or user studies is a plus
Working closely with lab members across domains

content.text: Please contact the D-REP co-directors (Sandra and Takanori) to apply.

We welcome both University of Arizona undergraduates and undergraduates from other universities, who are interested in gaining research experience in the areas of machine learning, visualization, digital fabrication, user-centered research inquiry, and experimental characterization. We discourage one-semester-only involvement, as many components of our research (computational design, fabrication, user studies, prototyping) require onboarding.
Students interested in long-term (one year or more) intensive research projects are encouraged to contact the D-REP co-directors (Sandra and Takanori).

Undergraduates may participate in research voluntarily in the lab. However, to seek funding or course credits, UArizona undergraduates can check out here for funding opportunities. Including, Vertically Integrated Projects, Course-Based Research Undergraduate Experiences (CUREs) for course cre dits, Summer Research Institute (SRI) and College of Science Research Scholarship for funded opportunities.

For undergraduates outside of UArizona, you may seek funding opportunities from your home school.
